case_vignette:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after having a 2-minute episode of violent, jerky movements of his right arm at school. He was sweating profusely during the episode and did not lose consciousness. He remembers having felt a chill down his spine before the episode. Following the episode, he experienced weakness in the right arm and was not able to lift it above his head for 2 hours. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved with over-the-counter medication. He was born at term and his mother remembers him having an episode of jerky movements when he had a high-grade fever as a toddler. There is no family history of serious illness, although his father passed away in a motor vehicle accident approximately 1 year ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 94/54 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, electrolytes, calcium, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Absence seizure B) Tonic-clonic seizure C) Myoclonic seizure D) Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged-red fibers E) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

## Step 1: Identify the gender-specific references in the text.
The text contains the following gender-specific references: "An 8-year-old boy", "his mother", "his father".

## Step 2: Rewrite the text to remove the gender-specific references.
The text should be rewritten to remove the gender-specific references, making it more inclusive and neutral. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I experienced a 2-minute episode of violent, jerky movements in my right arm and I was sweating a lot during the episode. I also felt a chill down my spine before it started.
When did these symptoms first start occurring?
The symptoms started occurring three hours ago.
Do you have a history of similar episodes, or is this the first time?
I had a similar episode of jerky movements when I was a toddler and had a high-grade fever.
Are you currently taking any medications or received recent vaccinations?
No, I am not currently taking any medications or received recent vaccinations.
Do you have any family history of neurological disorders or epilepsy?
No, there is no family history of serious illness or neurological disorders.
Have you noticed any triggers or specific situations that precede these episodes?
I remember feeling a chill down my spine before the episode started, but there are no other specific situations or triggers that I've noticed.
Final Diagnosis: Focal Seizure.
